quoteFirst: It was the second dog-watch from
quoteLast: —and a grand but stormy-looking sunset had given place to the long twilight that prevails in these high latitudes.  A solitary star of great size blazed in the zenith, while on the northern horizon, resembling an immense open fan, there was a fine display of the Aurora Borealis, which appeared to rise out of the sea and was becoming more beautiful as the twilight deepened.
title: Rounding Cape Horn, and Other Sea Stories
author: McRoberts, Walter; Wright, Grant, 1865-1935 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: DOG-WATCH, a nautical term distinguishing two watches of two hours each (4 to 6 p.m. and
quoteLast: ). All the other watches count four hours each, and without the introduction of the dog-watches the same hours would always fall to be kept as watch by the same portion of the crew.
title:
The New Gresham Encyclopedia. Deposition to Eberswalde
Volume 4, Part 1
author: Various

quoteFirst: This extraordinary-looking turn-out continued its headlong course over bog-roads and through rough country lanes, to the astonishment of the inhabitants, till the lame farmer's house was reached. He was carefully lifted into the carriage, conveyed to the polling-place, and recorded his vote at
quoteLast: , with just six minutes to spare before the poll closed. As it turned out I won the seat by fifty-six votes, so this rapid journey was really superfluous, but we all thought that it would be a much closer thing.
title: Here, There and Everywhere
author: Hamilton, Frederic, Lord, 1856-1928

quoteFirst: DOG-WATCH, a nautical term distinguishing two watches of two hours each (4 to 6 p.m. and
quoteLast: ). All the other watches count four hours each, and without the introduction of the dog-watches the same hours would always fall to be kept as watch by the same portion of the crew.
title:
The New Gresham Encyclopedia. Deposition to Eberswalde
Volume 4, Part 1
author: Various

quoteFirst: In the dog-watches of the evening, after supper, from
quoteLast: , the blue-jacket is given his leisure. It is then that pipes are smoked, vigilance relaxed, boxing and wrestling bouts are in order, and Jacky settles down for his rest after the day of labor.
title: Pike & Cutlass: Hero Tales of Our Navy
author: Gibbs, George, 1870-1942

quoteFirst: P.M., and the larboard from
quoteLast: , when the watch is set. They are thus changed every night, one having eight hours on deck and four below one night, and the next _vice versa_, continuing thus for the voyage.
title: Life and Adventure in the South Pacific
author: Jones, John D.

quoteFirst: The second dog-watch, from
quoteTime: six to eight in the evening
quoteLast: , is the sailor's play-time. Unless some emergency requires it, drills and duties are suspended for the time being and Jackie, except for supper, has his time to himself.
title:

quoteFirst: At
quoteLast: she opened the door, and came out. She had simply flown into her clothes, in ten minutes! Her eyes were still black as night with resentment, and her bosom rose and fell, while in her white cheeks two scarlet spots flamed.
title: The Reason Why
author: Glyn, Elinor, 1864-1943

quoteFirst: The high winds across the ocean may have caused his car to deviate slightly from its path, so as soon as land appears the deviation has to be corrected, and only two or three seconds remain in which to correct it. However, the engineer is equal to his task, and the car is now in the same manner as before, brought to a stand in Galway at
quoteLast: , just 30 minutes out from St. John's and 54 from Halifax. At 8 o'clock Dublin is reached, next comes Holyhead, and then London at 8.20.
title: The Dominion in 1983
author: Centennius, Ralph

quoteFirst: Very soon Pat Francis dropped off De Molay Four, slowing at Elcho, ran straight to the operator for his order, signed it and at once Order 79 was throbbing back to young Giddings at Medicine Bend. It was precisely
quoteLast: when Giddings gave back the Complete and at 7.55 Elcho reported Special 326, "out," all just like clockwork. What a head Martin Duffy has, thought young Giddings--and behold! all the complicated everlasting headwork of the trick and the day, and of the West End and its honor, was now up to the signature of Third Eighty at Rat River.
title: Held for Orders: Being Stories of Railroad Life
author: Spearman, Frank H. (Frank Hamilton), 1859-1937; Hambidge, Jay, 1867-1924 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: Twice a day, if the captain gave the order, he had to open this room, to serve out provisions to the cooks of the messes, weighing every atom with scrupulous care. The times of serving out were generally from seven to nine in the morning, and from
quoteTime: six to eight in the evening
quoteLast: . To encourage him to be careful and thrifty he received a bonus on the provisions remaining with him at the end of a cruise, when the ship was paid off. He also received 10 per cent. on all sums paid to the crew “for savings of provisions.
title: Sea life in Nelson's time
author: Masefield, John, 1878-1967

title: Sir Charles Warren and Spion Kop: A Vindication
